title-group.article-title: Is Breastfeeding Truly Cost Free? Income Consequences of Breastfeeding for Women

author-notes.corresp: Phyllis L. F. Rippeyoung, Acadia University, Department of Sociology, 10 Highland Avenue, BAC 302, Wolfville, Nova Scotia, Canada B4P 2R6 E-mail: phyllis.rippeyoung@acadiau.ca

fn.p: Phyllis L. F. Rippeyoung is an Assistant Professor of Sociology and Coordinator of Women’s and Gender Studies at Acadia University in Wolfville, NS, Canada. She teaches courses in research methods, statistics, social stratification, work, and gender. Her research has examined inequality in early childhood and gender inequality in the workplace and in families. Currently, she is focusing on how infant feeding choices influence gender inequality and is beginning qualitative research examining how breastfeeding impacts the division of labor in lesbian families in Canada and the United States.

Mary C. Noonan is an Associate Professor of Sociology at the University of Iowa. Her research explores the relationship between gender, family responsibilities, and work outcomes. Prior work focuses on the sex-based earnings and promotion gap among lawyers. Other research explores how policies at the federal and state level affect the work decisions of American women. Her new work investigates the use of family-friendly policies on employees’ work hours and earnings.

abstract.p: Based on studies showing health advantages for breastfeeding mothers and their infants, pediatricians and other breastfeeding advocates encourage new mothers to breastfeed their babies for at least the first six months of their infants’ lives, arguing that breast milk is best for infants, families, and society, and it is cost free. Few empirical studies, however, document how the decision to breastfeed instead of formula-feed is associated with women’s post-birth earnings. This is an important omission, given that the majority of women today work for pay, and many work in job environments incompatible with breastfeeding. Using data from the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth, our results show that mothers who breastfeed for six months or longer suffer more severe and more prolonged earnings losses than do mothers who breastfeed for shorter durations or not at all. The larger post-birth drop in earnings for long-duration breastfeeders is due to a larger reduction in labor supply. We discuss the implications of these findings for gender equality at home and at work.

body.p: Gender inequality is a central theme within sociological theorizing and research. Huber recently put forth a convincing sociobiological theory in her book On the Origins of Gender Inequality (2007). She locates the root cause of gender inequality in the unique patterns of human reproduction and neonatal development that lead to infants’ need to breastfeed. Huber makes no case against women breastfeeding but argues that patterns of human lactation have historically kept women out of the loop of power, as they were constrained to feeding babies rather than going out hunting or ruling.

Although Huber makes a compelling case for the central role of human reproduction and its concomitant responsibilities in creating gender inequity, and many scholars have examined the role of motherhood in explaining current gender inequality, little empirical research explores how infant feeding practices may contribute to gender inequality today. In this article, we address this gap in the literature using the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth (NLSY) to explore the following questions: (1) Do breastfeeding mothers pay a greater economic penalty in earnings compared to formula-feeding mothers after childbirth? (2) If so, are penalties short- or long-term? (3) What mechanisms can explain these potential penalties (e.g., reduced work hours or time out of the labor force)?

Citing numerous health benefits of breastfeeding for mothers and children, the public health community has made a massive push to get mothers to breastfeed (Wolf 2003). As a result, understanding economic consequences of breastfeeding on women’s lives is essential. However, until the mid-1990s, neither feminists nor sociologists critically examined the topic of breastfeeding, despite considerable attention paid to childbirth and women’s health generally (Carter 1995). This is surprising considering that lactation is something women’s bodies do (Hausman 2003) and substantial empirical evidence shows that coupling full-time paid employment with breastfeeding is a challenge for many women (Galtry 1997; Gatrell 2007; Kimbro 2006; Lindberg 1996).

One reason why there is little critical analysis on the potential negative consequences of breastfeeding for women’s lives is because, until the 1990s, scholars and activists were focused on the problematic practices of formula manufacturers, particularly in the global south. There appeared to be general agreement among feminists, especially those in the women’s health movement, that breast was “best” for babies and the introduction of formula undermined women’s autonomy and turned lactation into a medical science (Blum 1999; Wall 2001). More recently, however, new feminist voices have begun challenging the scientific evidence on the benefits of breastfeeding, arguing that breastfeeding promotion smacks of biological determinism and denies the challenges women face in trying to breastfeed (Blum 1999; Carter 1995; Hausman 2003). Some writers argue that the benefits of breastfeeding are being oversold, and pressuring women to breastfeed when they are unable or uninterested harms them (Law 2000; Rosin 2009; Wolf 2007).

In this article, we attempt to strike a path between these two opposing views by exploring an issue that feminists of all stripes should be concerned with: how to reconcile potential conflicts between women’s biological and socioeconomic realities. Our main goal is not to advocate breastfeeding over formula- feeding or vice versa, but rather to examine whether mothers who work outside the home pre-birth face different income trajectories after birth as a function of type of infant feeding. Results from this study will be useful to policymakers concerned with gender equity in the workplace and those interested in increasing overall rates of breastfeeding.

sec.title: Review of the Literature
sec.p: Breastfeeding has been promoted as “best” for babies and mothers by the American Academy of Pediatrics (2005), the World Health Organization (2003), the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (2000), and most parenting manuals, magazines, and guides (Wolf 2003). Overall, compared with formula-feeding, proponents argue that breastfeeding is simpler, safer, healthier, and, for the most part, cost free (Barber-Madden, Petschek, and Pakter 1987; U.S. HHS 2000). Based on results from hundreds of studies, numerous organizations, agencies, and parenting experts argue that breastfeeding provides benefits for infant and maternal health, mother-child bonding, and the environment. Most health experts encourage mothers to exclusively breastfeed their babies (i.e., no water, formula, other liquids, or solids) for the first six months of their infants’ lives; newer recommendations suggest mothers continue to breastfeed their children to the age of one (American Academy of Pediatrics 2005) or even two years old and beyond (WHO 2003).

Breastfeeding rates in the United States have oscillated over the past 40 years and the majority of women have never met the recommended duration (CDC 2010). According to their analysis of the Ross Laboratories Mothers Survey, Ryan, Wenjun, and Acosta (2002) report that breastfeeding initiation rates in the hospital were low in the 1960s and hit their nadir of the past 40 years in 1971, with only 25 percent of mothers breastfeeding at all and 22 percent breastfeeding exclusively with no formula, water, or other supplements. However, rates increased steadily through the 1970s into the early 1980s, with 62 percent of mothers initiating breastfeeding in the hospital and 55 percent exclusively breastfeeding in the hospital in 1982. Breastfeeding rates then began declining in the 1980s, rose again in 1991, eventually surpassed the 1982 rate in 1997, and have continued to grow ever since (Ryan et al. 2002). The most recent data show that in 2007, 75 percent of women initiated breastfeeding, achieving the U.S. Health and Human Services “Healthy People 2010” goal for breastfeeding initiation (CDC 2010). Trends in the percent of women who breastfeed for the recommended duration of six months or longer followed a similar pattern (increasing over the 1970s, declining in the 1980s, and increasing over the 1990s), although the percentage is much lower, hitting a low of 5 percent in 1971 and a high of 43 percent in 2007 (CDC 2010; Ryan et al. 2002).

On the whole, previous research on breastfeeding focuses on two main areas: (1) identifying barriers to breastfeeding (e.g., Barber-Madden et al. 1987; Van Esterik and Greiner 1981) and (2) identifying benefits of breastfeeding for children and their mothers (for a review, see American Academy of Pediatrics 2005). To better understand the obstacles to breastfeeding, a large body of research identifies how mothers’ economic characteristics are related to initiation and duration of breastfeeding. Poor, less educated, and non-professional working women are less likely to breastfeed compared to non-poor, more educated, professional or non-employed women (Chatterji and Frick 2005; Haider, Jacknowitz, and Schoeni 2003; Khoury et al. 2005; Ryan, Wenjun, and Arensberg 2006). In this line of research, the causal relationship between women’s work characteristics and breastfeeding has been examined almost exclusively by assessing the effect of work characteristics (i.e., work status, hours, occupation, and earnings) on the likelihood of breastfeeding (e.g., Gielen et al. 1991; Kimbro 2006; Visness and Kennedy 1997). The literature shows a clear consensus that working is negatively related to breastfeeding duration, although working has less of an impact on whether a woman initiates breastfeeding (reviewed in Murtagh and Moulton 2010).

The question of what happens to a woman’s earnings once she begins to breastfeed, however, has not been adequately addressed. In fact, very little quantitative research examines how breastfeeding impacts women’s economic status (Kukla 2006; Law 2000; Rosin 2009; Wolf 2007), aside from research that tallies the saved expense of not purchasing formula, and the reduction in medical costs and fewer missed work days for mothers as a result of healthier children (Ball and Bennett 2001; Cohen, Mrtek, and Mrtek 1995; Weimer 2001).1 Furthermore, although a large body of work shows that motherhood, in general, has a negative effect on women’s wages (e.g., Budig and England 2001), none of the motherhood wage penalty research distinguishes mothers into groups based on type of infant feeding.

sec.title: Sociobiological Accounts of Breastfeeding and Gender Inequality
sec.p: In her sociobiological account of the origins of gender inequality, Huber (2007) argues that human beings’ evolution to bipedalism led to infants’ increased brain size. This meant childbirth needed to happen earlier than in other primates and it delayed “much more of the brain’s growth to the postnatal period” (p. 70). Human infants are born more helpless than other primates; they require a mother’s constant care for protection and her breast milk for the nutrients other primates would receive in utero:

disp-quote.p: Until the end of her reproductive period, a typical mother had to carry her youngest child everywhere she went and sleep with it at night for three or four years to boot because her low-fat milk sated the infant’s hunger only briefly. . . . She gathered nuts, berries, and killed small animals on a daily basis, all of her children in tow, to provide food for them and teach them to provide for themselves when they were almost fully grown. These obligations barred her from a number of activities, which, unfortunately, included those that typically contributed the most to male power and prestige. (Huber 2007:71)

sec.p: Although Huber clearly demonstrates the benefits of breast milk and its absolute necessity for survival through most of human history, she nonetheless shows the central role that women’s caretaking during neonatal and early childhood periods has played in women’s subordinate role to men throughout time, which has consequently affected women’s work lives.

Huber (2007:93) argues that a major social cost of breastfeeding is in the opportunity cost of mothers’ time, because “the need to feed an infant often precludes the mother’s engaging in a variety of other activities.” Consequently, relative to men, women are unable to participate in the social life of the group due to the demands made on them as nursing mothers. Throughout history, if a mother has wanted or needed to engage in work outside the home she has had to choose between abandoning her infant, employing a wet nurse, or feeding the infant something other than breast milk. Prior to the introduction of formula, feeding an infant anything except breast milk was associated with extremely high rates of infant mortality because of poor sanitation (estimates range between 80 and 90 percent [Huber 2007:114]), and wet nurses were available to only a privileged few (Fildes 1986).

Although scholars point to a number of factors to explain the increase in women’s employment over time (e.g., rise in labor demand and increased control of fertility), Huber argues that the rise in women’s employment and increasing visibility in public life was due in large part to the advent of modern theories of sanitation in the early 1900s and the resultant introduction of formula. As Huber notes in her introduction, the importance of formula-feeding as a cause of the rise in women’s labor force participation in the twentieth century is evident in the fact that women’s labor force entry coincided with the introduction of formula. In a quantitative analysis, Albanesi and Olivetti (2009) also find that the introduction of formula and advances in obstetrics are significant explanators of women’s increased labor force participation over the twentieth century.

sec.title: Structural Constraints to Combining Work and Breastfeeding
sec.p: Formula contributed to women’s entry into the workforce partly because little else has been done to address the structural constraints limiting women’s ability to combine breastfeeding with work (Galtry 1997; Gatrell 2007; Hausman 2007). Few gains have been made toward creating breastfeeding-friendly workplaces in the United States (Blum 1999; Ryan et al. 2006). Until passage of the “reasonable break time” provision of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010, there were no federal legal protections for mothers to breastfeed at work. Mothers who attempt to work and pump/express milk on the job may thus face many difficulties, such as unsupportive co-workers, lack of a private place to nurse or express milk, or no place to store expressed milk.

Many empirical studies document the difficulty in coupling work and breastfeeding (e.g., Fein and Roe 1998; Kimbro 2006; Kurinij, Shiono, and Rhoads 1988; Reynolds 2005; Roe et al. 1999). For instance, in her qualitative account of women’s experiences combining breastfeeding with work in the United Kingdom, Gatrell (2007:403) found that many breastfeeding mothers felt unsupported in their workplaces and that they had to hide their “leaky lactating bodies” from their employers and colleagues. Reynolds (2005) found, in her nonrandom sample of Canadian mothers, that many breastfeeding mothers had great difficulty coupling work and breastfeeding; to cope, women used a variety of strategies, including discontinuing breastfeeding, reducing their work hours, changing employers, or quitting work entirely. These difficulties would only intensify as a woman breastfeeds for a longer duration, because combining breastfeeding and work for a short period is likely easier than for a long period.

Breastfeeding mothers may be more likely than non-breastfeeding mothers to reduce their work hours, because breastfeeding is more time-intensive than formula-feeding. Because formula digests more slowly than breast milk, formula-fed babies usually need to eat less often than breastfed babies (Massachusetts Department of Public Health 2004). Additionally, even if a non-maternal caregiver feeds an infant with the mother’s expressed breastmilk, a substantial time commitment is required of the mother to express her milk via a breast pump or manual massage. Using formula to feed an infant requires little time beyond the act of feeding and does not necessarily require any more time of the mother than of anyone else. Thus, a decision to breastfeed instead of formula-feed will likely necessitate more of a mother’s time on infant feeding and less time at work, all else constant. Working fewer hours in the labor force means lower annual earnings in the short-term, and research suggests that part-time work has a permanent depressive effect on future earnings trajectories (Connolly and Gregory 2009).

One of the most significant ways that breastfeeding could affect working women’s earnings is if women take extended unpaid maternity leave or quit their jobs post-birth. The likelihood of extending maternity leave or quitting work is greater for a mother who breastfeeds her child compared to one who formula-feeds, all else being similar, because breastfeeding is less compatible with paid work and business travel. In fact, quantitative research shows a positive association between length of maternity leave and breastfeeding rates in Canada (Baker and Milligan 2008) and the United States (Guendelman et al. 2009).

If women quit work entirely to have extended breastfeeding time with their babies, they lose earnings in the short-term that they would have made if they had not quit. As one of Hays’s (1996:77) respondents noted about her decision to take a six-month maternity leave:

disp-quote.p: The first time cost me $20,000 in savings to nurse her for six months. That’s what I burned through by staying home! I couldn’t afford to do that the second time. You can think you’re going to nurse for six months, but wait ’til you see what that costs when your salary isn’t coming in. [She laughs.]

sec.p: The decision to leave the labor force may also negatively affect women in the long-term if they decide to return to work after the break (Arun, Arun, and Borooah 2004; Spivey 2005). During their time away from paid work, women may lose out on promotions that come with increased experience, they may become deskilled, or they may find less compatible work when they attempt to reenter the labor market (Mincer and Polachek 1974).

Only one prior quantitative study directly examines the impact of breastfeeding on women’s work lives. Roe and colleagues (1999) assessed whether there is competition between breastfeeding and maternal employment using 1993 to 1994 data from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s Infant Feeding Practices Study. This longitudinal study surveyed mothers 11 separate times, beginning in late pregnancy through 12 months postpartum. The authors estimated a simultaneous equation model to determine the impact of breastfeeding duration on work-leave duration concurrently with the impact of work-leave duration on breastfeeding duration. Results show that “at both times [three and six months postpartum], the duration of work leave significantly affects the intensity of breastfeeding, but the reverse is generally not found” (Roe et al. 1999:157). Despite the importance of their findings, their study does not tell us (1) if there are long-term effects of breastfeeding on work outcomes among women who breastfeed (because they only follow their sample for 12 months postpartum); (2) if there is a unique “breastfeeding effect” apart from a “motherhood effect” because they only examine mothers who initiated breastfeeding in their research (they do not include formula-feeding mothers); and (3) if breastfeeding affects other work outcomes beyond work leave, such as earnings growth over time.

sec.title: Pressures to Breastfeed
sec.p: The conflict between paid employment and breastfeeding has become more prominent since the 1970s with the dramatic increase in the proportion of mothers of newborns currently in the work force (Solis and Hall 2010). At the same time, research shows that women today believe that breastfeeding is important to their sense of being good mothers:

disp-quote.p: All the women in our study believed that breastfeeding was “natural,” and therefore desirable, crucial to their relationship with their baby and best for their baby’s health. Furthermore, breastfeeding represented “good” mothering. Most women were prepared to “persevere” with breastfeeding to achieve their identity as a breastfeeding mother. This is particularly clear in Jane’s account: “I think [breastfeeding] is a major motherhood thing, that you have to try and persevere and accomplish.” Breastfeeding was something that the women wanted to master, to get under control. (Schmied and Lupton 2001:238)

sec.p: Because most women aim to breastfeed, Schmied and Lupton (2001) and others (e.g., Rosin 2009; Taylor and Wallace 2010; Wolf 2007) point to the potential for women to experience guilt or shame for quitting breastfeeding (or not breastfeeding at all) because they believe they are not being “good mothers.”

Women are not only told that breastfeeding is important for being a good mother, but major breastfeeding advocacy groups also instruct them to prioritize breastfeeding over paid work. For instance, La Leche League, the world’s largest organization dedicated to the support of women breastfeeding, has a history of discouraging new mothers from working (Blum 1999). According to Blum (1999), the organization consistently argues for maximizing mother-to-child contact and ignores issues faced by working mothers. It was not until the third edition of their book, The Womanly Art of Breastfeeding,2 was published in 1981 that the organization addressed the topic of paid work for new mothers: the book suggested new mothers work only part-time if they must work. Although La Leche League has increasingly recognized the need for women to work, Blum (1999:79) found in her interviews with leaders that to be a “League role model was to have ‘no regularly scheduled separations from [one’s] baby.’” One of the largest organizations for breastfeeding support has actively promoted the notion that family should come before work for new mothers.

Literature on the work-family conflict also shows that for many women family does indeed come before work, sometimes due to their preferences, often due to un-family-friendly workplaces (Gerson 1985; Hays 1996; Hochschild 1989; Stone 2007). It thus seems plausible that due either to the desire for the health benefits of breastfeeding or societal pressures to breastfeed, mothers who are employed before childbirth might reject work after childbirth in favor of breastfeeding if they have the financial means to do so, considering that to reject breastfeeding in favor of work would violate cultural norms of good mothering.

sec.title: Current Investigation
sec.p: Prior literature on breastfeeding shows that (1) women find it difficult to breastfeed while engaging in paid work (Kimbro 2006; Law 2000; Reynolds 2005; Roe et al. 1999); (2) women feel pressure to breastfeed (Schmied and Lupton 2001; Taylor and Wallace 2010; Wolf 2007); and (3) many women who face work-family conflicts opt out of work when they have the financial ability to do so (Stone 2007). Based on this literature, we hypothesize that mothers who breastfeed will have lower earnings in the short-term and potentially in the long-term, because they will be more likely to reduce their work hours or quit work entirely to accommodate the demands of breastfeeding.

To assess these hypotheses, we use the NLSY to determine whether breastfeeding mothers and formula-feeding mothers—who are employed in the year prior to childbirth—face different earnings trajectories after childbirth, holding demographic, family, and work characteristics constant. We examine earnings differences in the short term (one year after birth) and the long term (five years after birth).3 If earnings differ, we explore possible mechanisms for this difference, including potential differences in employment status and hours worked.

It is important to note that this analysis is descriptive and not a definitive causal test of the relationship between breastfeeding and women’s employment behavior and earnings. Simply finding support for the hypothesized relationship does not mean that breastfeeding will inevitably lead any breastfeeding woman to reduce her work hours, quit work, or face earnings loss. The possibility remains that an unmeasured variable (e.g., orientation toward work or family) is driving women’s employment behavior and choice of infant feeding. To definitively assess causality in this case, we would need an experimental design in which new mothers are randomly assigned to breastfeed or formula-feed and then surveyed at several time points post-childbirth about their employment behavior and income. Such a design is clearly unethical. Although our use of observational data does not allow us to definitively assess causality, we are able to determine probabilistic causation between type of infant feeding and women’s earnings, given that our analysis controls for many time-variant characteristics.

sec.title: Data
sec.p: We use data from the NLSY to address our research questions.4 Compared to cross-sectional data, longitudinal data give better insight into the potential long-term relationship between type of infant feeding and work outcomes. Longitudinal data allow us to document women’s pre- and post-birth work characteristics, identify any change in mothers’ earnings over time, and then see whether the magnitude and direction of such changes are related to type of infant feeding. NLSY data are a representative sample of 12,686 U.S. men and women age 14 to 22 years in 1979 (i.e., born 1957 to 1964). These data are particularly useful for our study because they provide detailed information on breastfeeding initiation and duration, as well as a host of work-related measures (United States Department of Labor 2006).

The NLSY interviewed women annually from 1979 until 1994, following which they were interviewed biennially. To have a pre-birth and birth year observation for each woman in our analytic sample, we included only women who gave birth to their first child5 between 1980 and 1993. We also eliminated women with non-singleton births or who were teenage mothers, and we excluded respondents with missing data on key measures. Because our interest is in the conflict between breastfeeding and work, we excluded mothers who were not employed at least 24 weeks (approximately six months) in the year prior to the birth. Our final sample includes 1,313 mothers. See Table A1 in the Appendix for details on sample restrictions and Table A2 for the distribution of birth years.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: Our dependent variable is current annual earnings. We recoded all dollar amounts into real (2000) dollars using the Consumer Price Index (CPI). We assigned zero earnings to women who did not work for pay at all in a given year. All mothers were included in the analysis, regardless of their work status post-birth. We logged earnings to correct for the positive skew in the distribution (because the log of $0 is not defined, we recoded non-employed mothers’ annual earnings to $1.00).

Our main independent variables are a combination of breastfeeding status and breastfeeding duration. Breastfeeding status is a dummy variable equal to 1 if the child was breastfed and equal to 0 if the child was formula fed. The survey reports breastfeeding duration as a continuous variable (i.e., number of weeks/months the child was breastfed);6 we recoded it into a dichotomous variable, indicating whether the child was breastfed for (1) less than six months or (2) six months or longer. Breastfeeding research commonly uses this categorization of breastfeeding duration (Jacknowitz 2008); it is based on the American Academy of Pediatrics recommendation that mothers breastfeed exclusively for at least six months, at which point solid foods can be introduced (American Academy of Pediatrics 2005). Finally, we generated three dummy variables based on breastfeeding status and duration: long-duration breastfeeders (breastfed for more than six months), short-duration breastfeeders (breastfed for less than six months), and exclusive formula-feeders (never breastfed).7

Our analysis explores whether mothers’ earnings following birth differ based on infant feeding type and duration. Assuming that differences do exist, we included a set of controls that research shows are correlated with the decision to breastfeed and employment outcomes. Our first set of controls measures demographics, including race/ethnicity (measured as a set of dummy variables indicating white, black, and other), nativity (measured as a dummy variable indicating whether a respondent was born in the United States), region of residence (dummy variable indicating whether a respondent lives in the South), and age (measured in years). We also included a control for education (measured as a set of dummy variables indicating less than a high school diploma, high school diploma, some college education, and college degree or higher) and two family characteristic variables, marital status (measured as a set of dummy variables indicating never married, married, and divorced/widowed) and number of children born (a continuous level variable indicating the number of children a respondent has in any given year). The final variable in this set of controls is a measure of women’s work commitment in 1979, which controls for women’s preferences about working.8 This item assesses whether a respondent would work if she were to get enough money to live comfortably without working; it is dummy coded such that a 1 indicates she would continue to work and a 0 indicates she would not.

The next set of controls consists of variables related to paid work. These include an indicator of employment status (a dummy variable equal to 1 if a respondent is not employed at all in the current calendar year, and equal to 1 if she is employed at least one week) and annual hours worked, a continuous measure of the total hours worked per year, ranging from 0 to 4,000.9 For respondents currently employed, we also include controls for current occupation (measured as a set of five dummy variables indicating managerial/professional, clerical, sales, service, and other) and industry (measured as a set of seven dummy variables indicating professional, trade, public administration, finance/business, manufacturing, transportation, and other).

Finally, we created a set of year dummy variables to capture changes over time in the wider culture that may influence mothers’ propensity to breastfeed and work. For example, over time medical recommendations may be revised, intensive mothering ideologies may shift, opportunities for women in higher education and the paid work force may increase, breastfeeding technology may change, or new family leave policies may be created, all of which could influence the likelihood of breastfeeding and working.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We trace effects of breastfeeding on earnings over time for a sample of mothers using growth curve models. Growth curve models are typically used to model and account for patterns of change over time, focusing on between-individual variation in the growth process (Singer and Willett 2003). In our case, growth curve models assume an underlying path of change over time in earnings for all mothers based on the average of individual trajectories but allow given characteristics (i.e., type and duration of infant feeding) to modify the path. These models will answer the question: do breastfeeding mothers have a lower earnings trajectory after birth compared to non-breastfeeding mothers? Our analytic technique requires that we observe at least two time points for each respondent but does not require that we observe the same number of time points for each respondent (Bliese and Ployhart 2002).10

Within the multiple linear regression (MLR) approach, growth curve models “can be construed as a standard two-level multilevel regression model” (Hox and Stoel 2005:1296). The level-1 model includes time variant characteristics that differ (or could differ) over time within individuals (e.g., marital status), and the level-2 model includes time invariant characteristics that differ between individuals (e.g., race). In these models, breastfeeding duration and status are treated as fixed characteristics based on each respondent’s final answers to the feeding questions after the child is 6 months old. This allows us to identify the earnings trajectories of the three distinct types of mothers (i.e., long-duration breastfeeders, short-duration breastfeeders, and exclusive formula-feeders).

We compared a number of nonlinear growth functions using a Maximum Likelihood estimator in Stata to determine which one best represented the data; our analysis revealed that a cubic function for time is the best fitting model. A cubic function allows for two bends, or inflections, in the earnings trajectory.
Equation 1 shows our level-1 baseline model:

In the level-1 model, Y is a woman’s CPI-adjusted annual earnings; subscript i refers to the individual respondent; subscript j refers to the time period; π0i is the intercept; π1i, π2i, and π3i are time slopes; and ϵij is the level-1 residual error term (Singer and Willett 2003). We coded time such that it is equal to 0 for the initial observation (the year prior to birth). Coefficients in Equation 1 are interpreted as follows: π0i represents average logged earnings in the pre-birth year; π1i *time, the linear term, represents the slope in logged income over time (we expect π1i < 0); π2i *time2, the squared term, adds a parabola shape to the earnings trajectory (we expect π2i > 0, meaning the decline in earnings will decelerate with time); and π3i *time3, the cubed term, adds a cubic s-shape to the trajectory (if π3i < 0 then earnings will dip again after plateauing; if π3i > 0 earnings will continue to increase).

The level-2 model consists of four equations (shown in Equations 2, 3, 4, and 5), one for each coefficient in the level-1 model. In each of these equations, we include dummy variables indicating infant feeding type and duration as predictor variables (formula-feeders are the omitted category). This allows us to test whether the type or duration of infant feeding is associated with initial level of earnings (π0i) and growth in earnings over time (π1i, π2i, π3i).

By incorporating a residual in Equation 2 (ς0i), we allow earning trajectories to vary among individuals in their starting point (π0i). The other slopes for time are fixed, although we allow for group differences based on infant feeding type and duration.
We combine the level-1 and level-2 models to form a single composite equation for our first model (shown in Equation 6):

Based on prior research, we expect that women who ever-breastfeed will have higher earnings in the pre-birth year compared to women who never breastfeed (γ01 > 0 and γ02 > 0). We expect that, on average, women will experience earnings decline after childbirth, and earnings decline will decelerate over time. We anticipate that breastfeeders will experience more of an economic penalty after birth than formula-feeders, and long-duration breastfeeders will experience more of a penalty than short-duration breastfeeders.

After estimating the main model, we estimated three additional models in which we sequentially added (1) year dummies, (2) demographic variables, and (3) work-related variables. In each model, we paid particular attention to the sum of the interaction coefficients for short-duration and long-duration breastfeeders for each time point:

list-item.p: time*long-duration breastfeeder (γ11) + time2*long-duration breastfeeder (γ21) + time3*long-duration breastfeeder (γ31), and
time*short-duration breastfeeder (γ12) + time2*short-duration breastfeeder (γ22) + time3*short-duration breastfeeder (γ32)

sec.p: The sums at each time point tell us if substantive differences exist in earnings trajectories among the three groups of mothers. We also carried out a Wald test to determine whether the short- and long-duration breastfeeders’ earnings trajectories are statistically different from one another.

sec.title: Descriptive Statistics
sec.p: Table 1 provides descriptive statistics of our three variables that do not vary over time—race, nativity, and work commitment—by infant feeding type and duration. To begin, we see that long-duration breastfeeders are the smallest subgroup of mothers (n = 219), and short-duration breastfeeders and formula-feeders are of larger and similar size (n = 519 and n = 575, respectively). As expected, breastfeeders are significantly more likely to be White and less likely to be Black compared to formula-feeders, and short-duration breastfeeders are more likely to be foreign-born compared to the other two groups. Additionally, formula-feeders are the least work committed, followed by long-duration breastfeeders. Short-duration breastfeeders are the most work committed, although the only statistically significant difference is between short-duration breastfeeders and formula-feeders.

caption.p: Descriptive Statistics on Fixed Covariates, by Infant Feeding Type and Duration, NLSY (1979 to 1994)

fn.p: Note: Data are weighted.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Statistically significant difference between short- and long-duration breastfeeders, p ≤ .05.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Statistically significant difference between short-duration breastfeeders and exclusive formula-feeders, p ≤ .05.

fn.label: c
fn.p: Statistically significant difference between long-duration breastfeeders and exclusive formula-feeders, p ≤ .05.

sec.p: Table 2 provides descriptive statistics for our time-varying variables by infant feeding type and duration at four separate time points. Beginning with the year prior to the birth of the baby (see Table 2, Panel A), we see that breastfeeders earn more than formula-feeding mothers. Short-duration breastfeeders work more hours per year than the other two groups in the year prior to birth. On average, long-duration breastfeeders are the most likely, and formula-feeders the least likely, to work in managerial/professional occupations in the year prior to birth (46 and 19 percent, respectively). Formula-feeders are more likely than breastfeeders to be employed in service occupations in the pre-birth year. Similar differences also exist with respect to industry. For instance, 41 percent of long-duration breastfeeders work in a professional industry, but only 23 percent of formula-feeders are represented in this industry.

caption.p: Descriptive Statistics on Time-Varying Covariates, by Infant Feeding Type and Duration and Year Surrounding Birth, NLSY (1979 to 1993)

fn.p: Note: Data are weighted. Less than 2 percent of respondents changed education or region of residence. Therefore, we do not display values for these statistics over time.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Statistically significant difference between short- and long-duration breastfeeders, p ≤ .05.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Statistically significant difference between short-duration breastfeeders and exclusive formula-feeders, p ≤ .05.

fn.label: c
fn.p: Statistically significant difference between long-duration breastfeeders and exclusive formula-feeders, p ≤ .05.

sec.p: On average, long-duration breastfeeders have significantly higher levels of educational attainment compared with short-duration breastfeeders and formula-feeders. Breastfeeders are, on average, about 25 years old in the year prior to first birth, whereas formula-feeders are about 23 years old. Breastfeeders are more likely to be married and less likely to be never married than are formula-feeders in the year prior to the birth. Finally, formula-feeders are more likely to live in the South compared to breastfeeders.

In the year of the child’s birth, we see a decline in average earnings for all three groups of mothers (see Table 2, Panel B). The percentage drop in earnings is most extreme for long-duration breastfeeders and more modest (and similar) for short-duration breastfeeders and formula-feeders. The decline in earnings is so dramatic for long-duration breastfeeders that they earn similar amounts of income as formula-feeders in the post-birth year. Short-duration breastfeeders and formula-feeders work more hours than long-duration breastfeeders in the year of the birth. Pre-birth differences in occupation/industry across groups remain in the birth year.

In the year following a child’s birth (see Table 2, Panel C), earnings and labor supply for all three groups of mothers increase slightly, on average. By the fifth year after birth (see Table 2, Panel D), the labor supply of long-duration breastfeeders has increased slightly but still lags behind formula-feeders and short-duration breastfeeders. Another important difference between the three groups at this stage is the average number of children each has: long-duration breastfeeders have significantly more children (2.06) than do formula-feeders (1.79) or short-duration breastfeeders (1.83).

sec.title: Growth Model Results
sec.p: Table 3 shows regression results of our growth models predicting income. In these models, we include up to a maximum of seven observations per woman (i.e., the year before childbirth, the birth year, and five years following the birth). Model A includes a variable for time and indicators of infant feeding type and duration (the omitted group is formula-feeders).

caption.p: Growth Model Regression Results Predicting Ln Income, NLSY (1979 to 1993) (N observations = 7,557; Nmothers = 1,313)

tr.td: Ln Annual Hours (1 to 1,749 hours), γ140

fn.p: Note: Standard errors in parentheses. Demographic controls include age, race, nativity, number of children, marital status, education, work commitment, and region of residence.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Omitted group is formula-feeders.
p ≤ .05; **p ≤ .01; ***p ≤ .001 (two-tailed tests). ^ Long-duration coefficient significantly different from analogous short-duration coefficients at p ≤ .05.

sec.p: To facilitate interpretation of our regression results, we use estimated coefficients from Model A to create a figure of the ln earnings trajectory for the three groups of mothers in the period surrounding first childbirth (see Figure 1). In the year prior to childbirth, both breastfeeding groups earned higher incomes than formula-feeders. In the birth year, all mothers’ earnings are lower regardless of infant feeding type or duration. Earnings stop declining after the child is two years old, on average, but remain much lower post-birth than pre-birth through the fifth year post-birth. Most important for this study, results show that long-duration breastfeeders’ earnings drop more precipitously in the year after having a baby and their post-birth earnings trajectory remains lower than for the other two groups of mothers.

caption.p: Mothers’ Ln Income Trajectory by Infant Feeding Type and Duration, Based on Model A in Table 3

sec.p: Our next model (Model B) includes year dummies; earnings trajectories—our main focus—of long-duration breastfeeders still differ significantly from the other two groups. Model C adds all of our demographic controls—age, race, region, marital status, education, number of children, and work commitment. Education and work commitment are positively related to earnings (results not shown). Compared to married women, divorced women earn more, and children are negatively associated with earnings. Inclusion of the controls, however, does not explain away the significantly more negative income trajectory for long-duration breastfeeders.

In our final model (Model D) we include controls for employment status, hours worked per year, and occupation and industry. Coefficients representing short- and long-duration breastfeeders’ earnings trajectories are no longer statistically different from one another. Additionally, coefficients representing the difference between long-duration breastfeeders’ earnings trajectories and that of formula-feeders are nearly (although not entirely) all nonsignificant in Model D. This means that a major explanation for differences in earnings trajectories between the two groups is differences in employment status and hours worked. Finally, residuals (σϵ) in Model D are substantially smaller with inclusion of the work-related variables, indicating that the amount of time spent working explains much of the difference in earnings trajectories between groups.11

As a sensitivity analysis, we reanalyzed the growth models using a continuous measure of breastfeeding duration, instead of the categorical measure (i.e., formula-feeders, short-duration breastfeeders, and long-duration breastfeeders). In these models, breastfeeding duration is simply equal to 0 for formula-feeders. Table A4 in the Appendix presents the results, which are substantively similar to those in Table 3. The earnings trajectory after childbirth is more negative as breastfeeding duration increases (see significant coefficients for γ11, γ21, and γ31). However, the breastfeeding duration penalty is almost entirely explained away after controlling for employment status and hours worked (compare γ11, γ21, and γ31 coefficients in Models C and D).

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, we explored the relationship between infant feeding type and earnings for a sample of first-time mothers. Unlike most previous studies exploring women’s work characteristics and infant feeding type, we focused on changes in earnings after childbirth as a function of infant feeding type. We categorized mothers into three groups based on the type and duration of feeding method: formula-feeders, short-duration breastfeeders, and long-duration breastfeeders. We found that after childbirth, short-duration breastfeeders and formula-feeders experienced similar earnings penalties. Although short-duration breastfeeders earned more money than formula-feeders in the five years following the birth, their earnings trajectories were not significantly different.

By contrast, women who breastfed for long durations experienced a much steeper decline in earned income over the first five years of their children’s lives. Our results suggest that breastfeeding, at least for six months or longer, is not free in an economic sense. Long-duration breastfeeders forgo substantial income after birth compared to short-duration breastfeeders and formula-feeders. The larger earnings reduction faced by long-duration breastfeeders is largely explained by differences in labor supply; long-duration breastfeeders are more likely to be non-employed in the years following childbirth and they work fewer hours when they are employed. These findings are in line with Huber’s (2007) historical account showing that breastfeeding has been an impediment to women’s full participation in public life—women who breastfeed are more likely to exit the public sphere for the private.

With these data it is difficult to determine why long-duration breastfeeders reduce their labor supply after childbirth to a greater extent compared to short-duration breastfeeders and formula-feeders. Some might argue that these mothers reduce their paid work time, not because of the difficulty of combining breastfeeding and work (as we hypothesize), but due to some other omitted factor. These critics might contend, for example, that more family-oriented women are more likely to breastfeed and leave the labor force after childbirth, but that one does not lead to the other. However, we control for early life-course work orientation in our growth models and results still show a negative relationship between long-duration breastfeeding and earnings.

It is possible that breastfeeding changes a woman’s attitudes toward working and family, making work less attractive and family more attractive. For example, mothers who have good breastfeeding experiences might decide that staying at home and continuing to breastfeed is preferable to working, and mothers with less positive breastfeeding experiences might decide that returning to work and stopping breastfeeding is preferable to staying at home. We cannot measure this because the NLSY data do not have yearly measures of attitudes toward work and family. If this reasoning is true, it would be incorrect to conclude that incompatibility between long-duration breastfeeding and paid work necessarily causes mothers to leave the labor force. However, even if there are other important omitted variables uncontrolled for in these analyses, our findings nonetheless demonstrate clear support for a pattern in which women who breastfeed for six months or longer work and earn less after childbirth than do their counterparts who breastfeed for less than six months.

One explanation for this has to do with cultural imperatives for mothers to put their children’s needs before their own—to practice what Hays (1996) refers to as an ideology of intensive motherhood. Because health advocates argue that breast milk is far superior to formula in terms of improving children’s health and intelligence, many women see breastfeeding as central to being a good parent. One can see this in the language of breastfeeding promotion that “breast is best,” which semantically links breastfeeding with doing what is best for one’s child (Wolf 2007). Breastfeeding for a long duration may be a proxy for intensive mothering, whereby some mothers are willing to sacrifice their work-lives and earnings to be (or even to be seen as) ideal mothers. If advocates argued that breastfeeding and working are best for children, perhaps these mothers would be more likely to couple long-duration breastfeeding with working.

Thus, the reasons why long-duration breastfeeders exit the labor force at higher rates than other mothers is difficult to tease out with these data. They may leave work because of their own personal desires or cultural pressure, or they may be pushed out because of the incompatibility of breastfeeding in the workplace. Further research that can more precisely explain the patterns we observe here is clearly warranted.

Despite a lack of precision as to why these patterns occur, we nonetheless see that the ability to intensively mother via long-duration breastfeeding is class-biased: on average, women who breastfeed are more likely to be married to college-educated men (results not shown), men who are capable of supporting a family during the period when wives reduce their labor supply. Privileged women are thus more likely to be disconnected from the labor force when they have children, and less-privileged women are less likely to be seen as good mothers. Because breastfeeding promotion focuses almost exclusively on encouraging women to breastfeed—without providing adequate economic and social supports to facilitate the practice—it reproduces gender, class, and racial inequality.

Assuming the relationship we document is due to incompatibility between work and family, we see a number of solutions. To avoid the loss of earnings, working mothers could simply replace breastfeeding with formula-feeding. This solution has drawbacks, however, considering the known health, environmental, social, and emotional benefits of breast feeding for women, children, and society at large. Furthermore, lactation is something that women’s bodies go through after the birth of a child and to deny women the ability to do so is to deny them control of their bodies. Rather than promoting formula, feminist breastfeeding advocates argue for the need to reconceptualize breastfeeding as a right (McCarter-Spaulding 2008):

disp-quote.p: Recognizing women’s right to breastfeed, as well as what it costs her (physically and economically) to do so, would begin to transform the expectation that she must or should do so on account of her baby. A country with breastfeeding-friendly workplace policies would, of course, be a better place for everyone to work, but it also would force men to acknowledge that their positions of power occur by virtue of women’s exclusion from the public sphere. (Hausman 2003:153)

sec.p: Rather than continuing to pressure women to breastfeed for their children’s well-being while providing no provisions for the sacrifices women must make to do so, an alternative solution would be to pass a federal law protecting women’s right to breastfeed at work. Until 2010, no federal legislation existed in this arena, which meant that employers were not bound by federal law to accommodate or not discriminate against breastfeeding mothers (Martin 2007). Section 4207 of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of 2010 includes protections for breastfeeding; however, they are quite limited and simply ensure that women get breaks to express their breast milk during the work day and that they have non-bathroom space within which to do so (USBC N.d.). Legislation more supportive of breastfeeding would include paid parental leave and onsite daycares, which allow women to breastfeed their children during the work day, so that breastfeeding does not have to become a disembodied practice involving machines and bottles (McCarter-Spaulding 2008).

In addition to these policy prescriptions, changing cultural prescriptions concerning appropriate roles for men and women within the family may ease the burden associated with breastfeeding and working, a burden that is currently placed solely on mothers. Although mothers’ partners can share many childrearing tasks, breastfeeding promotion focuses almost exclusively on mothers (Johnston and Esposito 2007). Partners should be encouraged and supported to carry out other domestic duties that would support breastfeeding and relieve women’s double burden (Draper 1996). More radically, evidence shows men’s ability to lactate (Baumslag and Michels 1995), at least to the point of being able to provide minimal milk and some nurturing for babies. There are many ways in which partner involvement could be promoted through public health campaigns. This would potentially help mothers more successfully balance work and family by reducing their domestic labor burdens, at least for women who are partnered (Rippeyoung and Noonan forthcoming).

Overall, our research contributes to the fields of gender stratification, feminist studies, and public health by drawing attention to a neglected explanation for the sex-based earnings gap by empirically documenting the relationship between infant feeding type, time at work, and earned income for a sample of mothers. The state emphasizes breastfeeding in its blueprints for infant health and argues that breastfeeding is free. Our research suggests that long-duration breastfeeding mothers forgo additional time in the labor market and this, in turn, depresses their earnings trajectories. Breastfeeding advocates and health professionals must recognize this hidden cost associated with breastfeeding because it may help to better understand why some women do not breastfeed. Moreover, because income is positively associated with health (Luo and Waite 2005), encouraging a mother to breastfeed at the cost of lowering the family’s income may not be the best way toward better health for mother and child. If the U.S. government wants to promote health and well-being for mothers and their infants, it should consider implementing federal legislation to protect the rights of mothers to breastfeed at the workplace or compensating them for the unpaid labor associated with this type of infant feeding (Smith and Ingham 2005). For the time being, despite catchy slogans, it remains to be seen if breast is always best.

tr.td: Mothers who had first child between 1980 and 1993
Mothers who had first child at age 18 or older
Mothers with singleton birth (i.e., exclude mothers with twins, triplets)
Mothers with non-missing data on key variables
Mothers with non-missing pre-birth year work status
Mothers who worked at least 24 weeks in the pre-birth year
Mothers with both pre-birth and birth year records
Person-year observations (average of 5.8 observations for each mother)

caption.p: Distribution of Child’s Birth Year, by Infant Feeding Type and Duration
Distribution of Breastfeeding Duration in Months
Growth Model Regression Results Predicting Logged Income, Continuous Measure of Breastfeeding Duration in Months, NLSY (1979 to 1993) (Nobservations = 7,557; Nmothers = 1,313)

tr.td: Ln Annual Hours (1 to 1,749 hours), γ140

fn.p: Note: Standard errors in parentheses. Demographic controls include age, race, nativity, number of children, marital status, education, work commitment, and region of residence.
p ≤ .05; **p ≤ .01; ***p ≤ .001 (two-tailed tests).

Breastfeeding advocates point to research that finds formula-fed infants are more likely to be sick than breastfed infants; breastfeeding employees may thus miss less work to care for sick children than would formula-feeding employees (Murtagh and Moulton 2010; U.S. HHS 2000). We do not explore this issue in the current study, because the magnitude of the relationship between type of infant feeding and number of sick days appears to be small (Cohen et al. 1995).

Uncovering the number of women who have read this particular book is difficult. According to Blum (1999), the second edition of The Womanly Art of Breastfeeding sold more than one million copies between 1963 and 1981. The most recent edition, the eighth, published in July 2010, has sold more than 45,000 copies as of May 2011; USA Today lists it as one of the top 150 best-selling books in all book categories and it is the only breastfeeding manual to make the list (La Leche League International 2010).

We examine women’s employment and earnings for the first five years after birth because women who stay out of paid employment to rear their children may return to work at this time, when public education begins for most children.
The NLSY is publicly available data and may be accessed at http://www.bls.gov/nls/nlsy79.htm.

Research suggests that a mother’s decision to breastfeed her second child is related to her breastfeeding experience with the first child (Nagy et al. 2001). To simplify our analysis, we limited our sample to the first child.
Table A3 in the Appendix shows the distribution of breastfeeding duration in months for all mothers in our sample.

We considered further categorizing breastfeeders into women who exclusively breastfeed and those who supplement with formula. However, data on formula-feeding were not collected for every year of our analysis. Between 1979 and 1990, the NLSY asked mothers to report whether they fed their babies formula, and if so, to report the child’s age in months when formula-feeding began and ended. As a sensitivity test, we restricted our sample to women who had their first child between 1980 and 1990 (approximately 90 percent of our sample) and used the formula-feeding question to distinguish between exclusive breastfeeders and supplemental breastfeeders. We found no statistically significant differences in earnings trajectories of these two groups.
The question on work commitment was asked only in the first year of the survey, 1979, when respondents were between 14 and 24 years old.

Ideally, we would like to test other possible reasons for differences in earnings post-birth, such as differences in length of maternity leave and switching to a job with a flexible schedule. Unfortunately, the NLSY did not collect data on these concepts for all years of the study. The NLSY gathered data on starting and ending dates of maternity leave and “hours of telecommuting” beginning in 1988. Data on the use of flexible work schedules were not collected in this survey during any year.

In each interview, respondents reported their current work status and family status and provided data on their annual income and annual work hours from the previous calendar year. To have all variables represent the current calendar year, we created two new variables representing current annual income and hours worked with data from the next year’s survey. Because the survey is biennial after 1994, current annual income and hours worked are missing after 1993. Therefore, we do not include any person-year observations after 1993 in the growth-curve analysis.

We considered including an indicator of husband’s income in our models. Our descriptive statistics show that husband’s income is higher among breastfeeders compared to formula-feeders and is highest among long-duration breastfeeders. Moreover, husband’s income is negatively correlated with mother’s employment status and work hours. In Model D, however, with mother’s hours worked and employment status included, husband’s income is not significant and does not substantively alter the magnitude or significance of our key variables. Results are available from the authors upon request.
